post: In our latest episode of Scholar Talks, BRI Senior Fellow Tony Williams is joined by historian John Bicknell to discuss the complex relationship between John C. Frémont and Abraham Lincoln and their differing approaches to slavery, emancipation, and presidential power. Drawing from his book Lincolns Pathfinder: John C. Frémont and the Violent Election of 1856, Bicknell discusses Frémonts controversial 1861 emancipation proclamation in Missouri, Lincolns revocation of the order, and how the presidents views evolved over timeultimately echoing Frémonts justification of military necessity in the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863. Watch it today!  https://bit.ly/4jMdADY

Meet BRIs 2025 Student Fellow, Yu-Cheng Liang! He is a junior at Camas High School in Camas, Washington. Most of his time is spent playing chess, where he is currently at the National Master rank. Besides chess, he loves to play the violin and study. BRIs Student Fellowship is a six-month educational program that helps high school students develop as leaders and develop skills in building civil society. Learn more about the Fellowship!  https://bit.ly/3f2q66h

High school studentsready to grow as a thinker, speaker, and leader? Join the Debate & Leadership Institute in historic Valley Forge! Engage in civil discourse, sharpen your leadership, and connect with peers from across the country. 🗓️ Apply by Friday, May 16 🎓 Open to rising 10th–12th graders 📍 Valley Forge, PA + Philadelphia day trip Built for students who want to lead with principle and purpose. https://bit.ly/3Z810qb

Happy Teacher Appreciation Week! 🎉 Today, we celebrate the incredible dedication and hard work of civics, history, and government teachers around the country who tackle complex topics and inspire students to understand and engage with the world around them. Teachers! We need your voice! Please take a moment to complete a brief survey to share your insights and experiences.  https://bit.ly/3RQEZIw

What defines legitimate executive power, and who holds the President accountable? Explore these questions in our new civic education resource ➡️ Government and Politics: Civics for the American Experiment. This free, customizable digital textbook, Government and Politics: Civics for the American Experiment, is ready for use in classrooms today or next school year! It covers all of the topics on the AP Government and Politics exam. This brand-new Core Resource contains primary sources, scholar-written essays, videos, tabletop games, and interactive elements!  https://bit.ly/3Z1NUe0

Secondary educators - you're invited to join the Bill of Rights Institute (BRI) for an in-person professional development seminar focused on enriching social studies instruction through the lens of freedom and civic responsibility. Participants will explore how foundational American principles and historical moments can be made accessible and meaningful for secondary students. Teachers will collaborate with one another and with BRI staff to build lesson ideas that are both engaging and aligned with standards. Participants will receive: - breakfast and lunch during the programming - a certificate for 6 contact hours - a chance to network with fellow teachers - Overnight accommodations will be provided for the first 10 registrants. All additional participants will have access to a discounted hotel rate. Register today!  https://bit.ly/4cZv8tt

Calling all student entrepreneurs and change makers in the St. Louis area! BRI's civic engagement contest is open to all Missouri-based young people who are between the ages of 13 and 19. All Missouri-based applicants to the national competition will be invited to exhibit their projects in-person on May 19th, 2025 at the MyImpact Challenge Missouri Fair. Students will have the opportunity to showcase their work and enter to win up to $2,000 at the Missouri Contest and eligible applications will automatically be entered for a chance to win a $10,000 national prize! Register Today!  https://bit.ly/4jYjfX5

Meet BRIs 2025 Student Fellow, Jonah Horwitz! He is a senior at Dunwoody High School in Atlanta. He serves as National Honor Society President, Model UN President, and DECA Vice President and is the Chief Finance Officer of the Junior Economic Club of Atlanta, is a varsity swimmer, and placed 4th in the National Personal Finance Challenge. Learn more about the Fellowship!  https://bit.ly/3f2q66h.

Meet BRIs 2025 Student Fellow, Naomi Obasa! She is a senior in the International Baccalaureate Diploma Program at Bay Shore High School in Bay Shore, New York. She is involved in clubs like Model UN, Student Council, and Brothers and Sisters Organization. This is her second year participating in the Bill of Rights fellowship and she is excited to learn even more about civics! Learn more about the Fellowship!  https://bit.ly/3f2q66h

Our MyImpact Challenge contest deadline is approaching! The contest is open until May 18, 2025, 11:59 pm. MyImpact Challenge is a nationwide civic engagement contest open to students ages 13-19. The contest highlights students actively engaged in service, volunteerism, or entrepreneurship in their communities. All complete applications are judged and winners are awarded cash prizes! Students start your profile today!  https://bit.ly/4lKiFho
